doc.repnme: Transcript of oral history interview with Richard Westebbe held on January 25, 1988
doc.abstracts: In January 25, 1988, Richard Westebbe was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert W. Oliver. During his tenure at the Bank from 1966 to 1991, Mr. Westebbe worked in the following areas: in the economics department as an advisor to the economics urbanization division (1966-1969); as division chief for the East-Central Delta Urban Region (ECDUR) (1969-1970); for the western Africa region as a senior economist (1971-1974, 1976-1987); in the international relations department as a team leader for the planning advisory division (1974-1976); and for the southern Africa region as a lead economist (1987-1990). He worked on missions to the Philippines, Mauritania, Gabon, Guinea-Bissau, and the Ivory Coast among others. He discusses how the World Bank was not doing program lending to Africa, and yet the economic reports were a basis of a dialogue with the countries on their policies. His transcript concerns the natural and industrial resources of Africa, mechanisms for mobilizing capital, and exchange rates contributing to the health of an economy.
